# Woah!
Steganography - 40 points

## Challenge 
> lel i haz good meme

> Author: Kevin Higgs

[meme.png](meme.png)

## Hint
> This hint is useless, along with everything else. Except for the file.

## Solution

### Part 1
Open in Stegsolve: Red/Green/Blue plane 0

There's some white pixels, may be LSB related. Let's use the same script in [Not_Quite_LSD](../Not_Quite_LSD/)
	
	./getlsd.py 
	

[Convert to ascii](https://www.rapidtables.com/convert/number/binary-to-ascii.html)

	n=117528486827789400165355036597757499772267701336144528618362083257361513763806238831790113655715882881718725332491830831528846581852724863384001329225122149955

--- 
### Part 2
Open in Stegsolve: Green plane 1

We see the text: `e = 3`

--- 

### Part 3

	$ strings meme.png | tail -1
	c=23273044714507614583919107642780731232409437015529456693716961465133831310123918470882082327335507219289041144186168765420579209702030715438341449893348841695639896994241125
---

### Solve!

Now we have all the RSA parameters.

Since e is very small, it could be a no-padding attack.
[Refer to what I did in the past](https://github.com/zst123/gryphonctf-2017-writeups/tree/master/Solved/NoWrap)


Quick python script

	e = 3
	c = 23273044714507614583919107642780731232409437015529456693716961465133831310123918470882082327335507219289041144186168765420579209702030715438341449893348841695639896994241125

	import gmpy2
	m = gmpy2.iroot(c, e)[0]
	flag = bytes.fromhex('%x' % m)
	print(flag.decode())


## Flag
`tpctf{rs4_and_st3g0_w0w}`
